Posts.Content: Mar 18, 2010 08:19AM llanabeth wrote: Everything went well, it was probably the easiest test so far. I did look over and saw things lit up on the screen but that was no surprise...  Now I wait a couple of days to find out what bone disease it is. And while I do that, I google everything I can about this disease and read and learn. My husband gets upset with me that I do but he doesn't understand that if I am going to live with this disease and fight it, I need to find out all I can about it. Knowledge is power.  If I had been better educated 2 years ago, I would not have believed my doctor when he told that since my mammogram was all clear as well as the ultrasound that there was NOTHING to worry about. The way I see it, you have one chance at this.  You better have a good game plan!
Posts.Title: Radioactive! llanabeth llanabeth

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2010 10:50AM llanabeth wrote: Thank you both! Right now am drinking so much water I made splash noises when I walk!
Posts.Title: Radioactive! llanabeth llanabeth

Posts.Content: Mar 22, 2010 04:29PM llanabeth wrote: Seems nobody can give me answers... there was mention of Paget's Disease of the bones... I get a CT Guided bone biopsy on Wednesday.  I guess it's the only way to know for sure.  So frustrating to wait while I KNOW this cancer festers inside. Sorry to be such a whiny one but It's getting harder to feel like a warrior when you hurry up wait wait hurry up wait wait... now I have to HURRY again and with 48 hours notice be getting a bone biopsy. and wait some more BLEH
Posts.Title: Radioactive! llanabeth llanabeth

Posts.Content: llanabeth wrote: Since last November, my tumor markers had shot up and since were slowly going up and up.  My Onc and I decided that Tamoxifen had ran out of it's magic and we decided to go with a combo of Falslodex and Lupron.  I had terrible side effects with Lupron, I ended up in the ER after being in excruciating pain for over 36 hours, also unable to keep anything down.  After that episode, my dr and I divided a plan to stop the pain and nausea next time (in 3 months). I received my first shots last month and a lil less than a month later took bloodwork and met with my Onc.  When i was in "remission" my makers were at 300 and had since shot up to 900.  so...................... less than a month into this new combo I was thrilled to hear him say that they went from 900 to 500! It was well worth the pain and side effects in my opinion and if I can manage those next time it will be even better.  I couldn't have asked for a better Christmas present this year.  This means more time with my 9 yr old and that means the world to me, pain or not! Merry christmas to all my Stage IV sisters, may your Christmas presents be as amazing as mine!  You are all in my prayers! Tamara Dx 2/18/2010, ILC, 2cm, Stage IV, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: BEST Christmas present ever! llanabeth lilylady

Posts.Content: llanabeth wrote: Im radioactive!  I was just injected Now I wait 3 hours and go back for my "photo shoot" and after that... MORE waiting for the results... so much waiting... I guess I may find out if the lesions picked up by the CT Scan were mets or arthritis. Isn't it funny to be heard saying outloud "Please let me have arthritis!!!" Tam Tamara Dx 2/18/2010, ILC, 2cm, Stage IV, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Radioactive! llanabeth llanabeth

Posts.Content: llanabeth wrote: Background:  I was diagnosed in January*ish" have not received any treatment of ANY kind due to lesions in my bones showing up.  Since then I have had CT Scans (2) MRIs (2), a Bone Scan and a CT Guide Bone Biopsy as well as regular X-rays. So far all imaging results have been "inconclusive" as to what IS causing the damage.  I get the biopsy result on Monday I went to pick up my Xray results yerterday and here is what the report says... ONLY 50% OF THE ANTERIOR ASPECT OF THE ACETABULUM COVERS THE FEMORAL HEAD. THERE IS ALSO A LYTIC LESION INVOLVING THE LEFT FEMORAL NECK MEASURING 4 X 3 CM. MOST OF THE FEMORAL NECK IS DESTROYED EXCEPT FOR THE MEDIAL CORTEX. THE PATIENT IS LIKELY AT RISK FOR PATHOLOGIC FRACTURE. Note: My Onc called an Ortho Surgeon when he got this result so I would be seen urgently, the ortho surgeon did not see any cause for alarm and said I could wait till next week. To be honest, I am scared to walk around or use the stairs in my house. And they STILL dont know what is eating away at my bones, let's hope Monday brings answers. Tamara Dx 2/18/2010, ILC, 2cm, Stage IV, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Frustrated at this whole horse and pony show llanabeth lovemyfamilysomuch

Posts.Content: llanabeth wrote: Not sure if this is a normal thing but I feel guilty that after years of having cancer, I am still alive and relatively well. I have lost many people to cancer and most of them went fast, very fast and here is me...  2.5 yrs after my official diagnosis and 5 yrs after my symptoms began... When I tell grandpa I feel great and am considered to be in remission, I feel bad because grandma did not have this chance.  When I talk to my cousin about how I feel... same guilt since her mother died of breast cancer rapidly also. I am fighting for my life yet I feel guilty that I am winning so far (knock on wood).  It's such a confusing feeling. Anybody else ever feel this way? Tamara Dx 2/18/2010, ILC, 2cm, Stage IV, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: Zometa vs. Xgeva penny4cats steelrose

Posts.Content: llanabeth wrote: I cant help but feel more should be done. Diagnosed early this year with ILC, weeks and weeks of scan this and that, biopsy this and that.  Mets to Spine, Pelvis, femur and "possibly" ribs. Before the confirmation of mets to bones, dr was "We're going to start chemo, then mastectomy, then more chemo and radiation" and I was ready to fight fight! Upon confirmation of Stage IV.  No more Surgery, no more chemo. "Here is a RX for Tamoxifen, take one a day" "The horse is out of the barn, we dont need to remove the cancer or do chemo" My femur was so destroyed, I just got a full hip replacement on April 3.  Recovery is taking forever to me it seems and will start Zometa next week and a bit of radiation on my hip. I just feel like the doctor has given up on me...  and I have NOT given up on me.  I still wanna fight this thing with everything I have so that I can see my 7 yrs old grow. Im sorry for being so whiny, at home and with my friends I put on this super brave face that says everything is gonna be allright but when im alone...  i get to feeling so desperate. Maybe this course of treatment is all that I need.  Dr assures me that the bone mets will be more of a "chronic" condition and since it's not in any of my organs, I will be just fine but I don't know.  I know he cant predict the future and that things can change at any given moment. I just wish I could control my panicky freak outs. =\ /whining off Thanks for letting me vent Tamara Dx 2/18/2010, ILC, 2cm, Stage IV, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Angry, Sad and Scared... llanabeth Frapp

Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2012 12:53AM llanabeth wrote: My bone mets were diagnosed first.  I saw the Dr for what I thought was a bad case of sciatica.  Needless to say, 3 days later I was getting a new hip while being diagnosed with breast cancer. It isn't rare in my opinion, I think they just like to shoosh us about it so that it appears to be a rare occurence.    If that makes any sense...

Meima - Thanks for posting this, you have given me a brighter outlook! *HUGS TO ALL* Thank you thank you!

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2012 09:47AM llanabeth wrote: To me personally (that is only me) I always told my husband/boyfriends that I was ok with them going to strip clubs.  In facr I prefer to know he is there than to know he is at a club.  At a strip club, the dancers are there to make money and they DO NOT want your man.  They punch in and out just like any other job.  At a club women would be all over your man, wanting to take him home to continue the party. The fact that he lied about it would totally piss me off and the fact that it's been for this long would doubly do so. Like someone else said, it doesnt matter what WE think.  YOU are the one that has to live with your decision. Good luck to you.

Posts.Title: Zometa vs. Xgeva penny4cats steelrose

Posts.Content: Apr 26, 2012 11:08AM llanabeth wrote: Janine! I have taken Zometa every month for over 2 yrs now.  Tylenol is said to help with flu like symptoms. When I first went for Tamoxifen, the following day I could barely get around from lower back pain and did some looking into SEs and this is what helped me. Drink a LOT of water, starting the evening before.  Make sure they drip it (tamoxifen) in slowly, ideally one hour; and drink more water during and all day after. This will flush your kidneys and you will feel no kidney pain (that is the back pain people feel).  It has worked with me for 2 years now.

Posts.Content: May 27, 2010 07:17PM llanabeth wrote: Thank you all and {{{{HUGS}}}} to all...  It's nice to see that I am not crazy. I do not cry in the shower, matter of fact the hot water makes me all happy... weird isnt it?  But the other day I was on my way to an apt and there was a good song on and I cranked it and was bopping and dancing and suddenly I was bawling like a toddler who had their lollipop stolen.  I had to be late for my apt so my tears would dry and my nose would not be red!  HAHA I do always feel a lot better after a good cry but...  it's hard to explain to my husband. For example.. the other he teased me about my age.  My husband and I have always teased each other about a ton of stuff.  Well this time it was as if he told me the worse possible thing in the world and I just crumbled and cried. When I think of it now I think its silly.  So maybe I will get my Pristique adjusted. Thank you ladies!
